title: Which Japanese car brand is better? - Quora

response.answer_text: If you are talking about quality and the ability to last a long time. I’ve driven these cars quite a lot. I’ve either owned them, or drove them at work multiple times, when I worked for a rental car company. Under the compact category- Toyota Corolla - Consumer Report’s number one pick. - The Toyota CEO told them to stop making boring cars, so they went hog wild crazy in the body design in the other direction. Smooth, quiet, ride, makes you think you are in a mini-luxury car. Honda Civic - Nice looks on the outside and much better handling and tracking than the Corolla. You will be noticed, plus if you can drive a manual, it is really a lot of fun, more so than the automatic version. 3rd place Hyundai Elantra- They get a much better basic warranty than the cars above. Under the midsize category- Honda Accord- I like the body style of it better than that of the Camry. But I’m no fan of turbo-charged engines (longevity concerns). Reliability has been good, but it is down a little bit from previous Accord’s. My last Accord achieved 307,194 over a period of more than 10 years, with NO major issues. Toyota Camry- It has some wild disjointed styling, but it is the car that I’d pick. The mileage is fantastic on the highway (I got 40 mpg on a 1,000 mile trip). My last Camry achieved 292,504 miles over 17 years with NO major issues. I guarantee, had another driver not t-boned it, I’d still be driving it today. Kia Optima- I now own have a Sonata, which is just as good. BUT, after experiencing the Optima, I would have chosen it had I tested it out, when I was looking. They are same underneath, but the Optima has better, more responsive handling. Also like the Hyundai, it comes with a long 5 year, 60,000 mile bumper to bumper warranty. The other brands only give you 3 year, 30,000 miles. Cars I would not recommend.- I love the Impala, but would not recommend any other GM car. They are going to stop making them, which means support will be a hassle in the future. Also, they have start/stop technology, which you cannot disengage. Infuriating! Love the Ford Fusion, when it comes to Ford. But they too are going to stop making them, so I think they have hurt themselves. Sure gas is cheap because of the Saudi-Opec gas war, but it will not stay that way. Lastly SUV’s- I am NOT a fan of SUV’s, definitely not the big one, or only a slight fan of the small ones. But based on exposure, if you absolutely have to follow the crowd. I’d say Hyundai Tucson and Sante Fe(small 4 or 5 passengers suv), excellent warranty, easy controls, smooth ride. Kia Sportage and Sorento, for the same reasons, as I would consider the Hyundai’s, just mentioned. I like the rugged looks of the new RAV 4, better. But I absolutely hate the ‘loud’ noisy interior, rattling engine, and rough ride. Honda CRV’s is a good car, but it has that little turbo charged engine and I’m not a fan of any car with those types of engine. Because any high pressure vehicle, is going to have a powertrain that is not going to last a longer as cars I’ve previously owned. Ford’s new Escape- Looks good, but I’d not buy it with a 3-cylinder engine (come on, give me a break). Large SUV’s- would never buy one (gas mileage is pitiful), but I did sample the new Hyundai Palisade. Not bad. Whew! Hope that helps.

I would say Toyota and Honda…mostly because there are so many of them that parts and repair info are easy to come by. That’s probably not an issue for you which points out that “better” will have a very personal slant. The only Japanese car I wouldn’t buy is a Subaru. They don’t last in hot weather (I live in FL) due to a genetic defect in the design of the motor. OK, bring on the outraged Subaru fans…a mighty wind of hot air… I always seem to get flak for that particular opinion. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- I guess we'll have to qualify me here in the signature: I'm a... teacher ex-multiple business owner glass artist mechanic salvage specialist school bus and heavy vehicle driver writer poster boy for lifetime learning Aside from work, I'm reading, gardening, cooking, researching, experimenting, volunteering, or doing something in or around the water or the woods. --------------- Resume --------------- If you could do it over, would you start a small business? -------------- Dave Bross's answer to What do you believe is the "key" to a happy life? How do you cope with your hardships with this "key"? If I pass on your question? It's because there's already a good answer posted, it's easily answered via search engine, it's ridiculous, or..... I just don't know the answer. I also don't usually answer questions on the weekend, sometimes a long weekend, but I will get to them later. Thanks! Dave
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Julia Anne and Yosef Karajeh

response.answer_text: They are all very similar. I've owned almost every Japanese brand over recent years.  It depends on what you consider better, and what subjective styling cues you find  compelling.  I'm not sure anyone would ever accuse Toyota of beautiful design, nor Subaru.  Nissan and Mazda try hard with design, to my eye, Nissan has some nicer cars visually.  Honda has faded to bland in the past few years, but they have loyal customers who buy their products anyway.  They ALL have had recalls and safety and reliability problems.  No car is perfect. Mechanically, they are all incredibly similar.  Many of them source parts from exactly the same suppliers, so even at the component level, they are somewhat the same.  They try to differentiate on engines and transmissions, but with the exception of Nissan, who is a major proponent of CVTs (continuously variable transmissions), they are all pretty much the same.  Engines are all pretty solid these days, and usually outlast the rest of the car.  Subaru has had some problems with engines (still have oil consumption problems) in recent years.  Mazda had some oil leak problems.  But in general, they are all pretty solid, if moderately boring.

Personally, my favorite Japanese car would have to be the Nissan GT-R also called the R35. While Nissan isn’t the first name that comes to you when it comes to a sports car, they have produced something that has rivaled the indomitable Porsche 911, one of the biggest names in high-end sports cars. This is the product of some truly remarkable Japanese engineering and a lot of technical marvels. That and a 3.8 Litre twin turbocharged V6 engine ,which is handmade, and produces somewhere around 500 BHP. The Nissan GT-R has a reputation for its brutal acceleration which propels this car from 0–62 mph ( 0–100 kmph) in under 3 seconds. It’s also known for its insane cornering abilities thanks to a very aerodynamic body and a slick four wheel drive system. In fact a modified version of the R35 set a record for fastest powerslide ever at some 350 kmph. I will admit it is not a pretty car and it is almost a decade old now and it may be cheap in other countries but in India it costs more than 10 Million Rupees which is more compared to how much you get it for abroad. But it still never fails to excite me or any car enthusiast for that matter. I have actually only seen the car once on the streets and it was certainly loud as hell. It is truly the zenith of what the Japanese can truly deliver. P.S I sincerely apologize for sounding like a Nissan salesman but this car is the only thing that occurred to me as the best Japanese car, as in what is quintessentially Japanese. I was first enticed by it when I saw reaction videos to it’s savage launch control. BTW my second favorite Japanese car would have to be the Lexus LFA which is a great car but just not as drastic, if you feel me. Let me remind you however that Jeremy Clarkson, a truly unforgiving person, said it was the best car he has ever driven and that deserves a ‘nuff said.

Extremely debatable, there is a lot more I could choose but with a short time, these are the one that I pick 1978 Mazda RX-7, it might have cost Mazda financially but it showed Mazda can prove the world of the Wankel rotary’s potential when it’s competitors gave up 1969 Datsun 240Z, it showed the world what Japan could do, it broke their car industry away from the image of conservative family saloons that had been presented to the west despite there were the Toyota 2000GT years before which went unnoticed because it’s high price 1989 Lexus LS400, because this is not Matt Farah’s Million Mile Lexus ;) Mainly because it it broke new grounds for luxury saloons further 1990 Honda NSX, when it came out, it was noted for its Honda Accord user-friendliness and practicality whilst retaining the character of its competitors which forced luxury car brands to adapt or die, which was why the Ferrari 348 (which came out just before) and numerous cars of the same class at the same time became underappreciated 2003 Toyota Prius, mainly it brought hybrid technology into public consciousness

Based on my experience, in Belgium. In my opinion, Nissan, because they have the Nissan Navara (Frontier), Nissan Titan, Nissan Patrol and Nissan GTR. They build cars that people have dignity driving. It’s true lately they’ve been using Renault engines and parts (and vice versa), but that’s what makes them look cooler. I prefer Nissan, but here’s my thought of other brands. Toyota… credits to their 4x4s, I’m in love with the Hilux and Land Cruiser. They also deserve credit for their hybrid models. Points lost to rest of their cars, very boring, weird design sometimes, and lack of character. Honda, I LOVE the new Civic, it looks cool! Honda cars are slightly more attractive than Toyota. Many people have told me that their reliability is superior, they just keep going, never stop. Mitsubishi, hard to find their dealers, and not many choices of models. Although, it kicked a lotta asses in rally and motorsports. Subaru, public presence is almost non-existent. If you do spot a Subaru or its dealer, you deserve to be in the world record stating how observant you are. However, like Mitsubishi, they also kicked a lot in motorsports. I was told that Subarus have this unique ability to start instantly, no matter how bad the conditions are… I don’t know how far it’s true.

Honda by a mile… Behold the magnificent S2000…  Ok, I hear you say, that's quite a nice looking roadster, but what's so special? Let me show you…  Not only is that one super cool, retro Knight Rider of a display but a rev counter that goes right up to 9 reaching peak horse power of 240 at just under 8000 rpm. A screaming banshee of an engine that just keeps going getting faster and faster and the drive more and more bonkers! This was mine half way through a 12 hour mission to get to a friends wedding. Most of it was spent somewhere between sideways and outright backwards.  We had no right to make it to that wedding but this girl got us there high as kites on pure adrenaline. So yes, clearly Honda are the kings of Japanese cars and that's without mentioning Pulp Fiction’s The Wolf’s car of choice…

response.answer_text: Without a doubt the Japanese consider Toyota to make the best cars in Japan. That said, a high end Nissan or Honda is going to be a better vehicle than a lesser priced Toyota, but if we are just talking about cars of the same class, then Toyota is the clear leader. Over my years in Japan, I have owned Japanese made by all the car makers. I have found Toyota to be the best to own and operate. On the other hand, my favorite car was a Mitsubishi Pajero. I loved that little jeep.  Toyota has 30% of the market, so I am not alone in my sentiments.

They are all very similar. I've owned almost every Japanese brand over recent years. It depends on what you consider better, and what subjective styling cues you find compelling. I'm not sure anyone would ever accuse Toyota of beautiful design, nor Subaru. Nissan and Mazda try hard with design, to my eye, Nissan has some nicer cars visually. Honda has faded to bland in the past few years, but they have loyal customers who buy their products anyway. They ALL have had recalls and safety and reliability problems. No car is perfect.

This is a tough nut to crack. While many will say that it's the Mark 4 Supra , others will argue that it's the 240Z , Skyline , 240SX , and what not. My personal pick would be the R34 Skyline Z Tune. This came with a much more spruced up engine from the factory line , the RB26DETT Z1. This was taken straight off the GT500 car and it made a whopping 500 HP. Just imagine. That kind of power is something, the most expensive cars of today make. And look at the R34. It's stunning. It's a work of art. It's just so simple. No fancy curvy lines , no fancy cuts , no big gaping intake holes , looks like your regular Skyline , but boy is that going to kick some serious bottom, even in today's standards. PS : Only 20 of them were ever made. Doesn't that add to the uniqueness factor entirely ? Shrvs

I am not sure in which aspect your thought of best , I assume that it's cheap and easy to maintain, All Japanese car manufacturers are good at making reliable cars which are easy to maintain compared to other country brands, since japanese brand toyota has been established in many countries from ages, it's no surprise that it has got good service network, spare parts availability and many after market options compared to other car brands, if you would like SUV styling toyota Rav-4 is best option, if sedan then camry would be best car to opt.

All cars today are far more reliable than cars in the past. This may seem counterintuitive in that cars today are so filled with computers, sensors, passive restraint systems and active safety systems as compared to cars in the past but it is really more of a testament to the better engineering and quality control that these systems have brought to the car making business. Specific to the question, all Japanese brands are more reliable on average than their competitors but the gap has narrowed so much that is is almost insignificant. Well, except for Jeep and Fiats I guess. If you look at JD Power rankings you will see one particular brand that is always at or near the top: Lexus. Sure, they are boring - even more boring that their Toyota brethren - but when it comes to pure reliability, boring is good.

They invest in great product rather than production as GMC. Nummi the GMC and Toyota venture which created the metro, Pontiac vibe. The Pontiac vibe has a Toyota corolla engine and the same as it's cousin's the Toyota matrix and Toyota Volts. The Pontiac vibe is a Pontiac with a Toyota corolla engine. These Pontiac vibes are hitting 400,000 miles with no problem and the GMC cars really never, only with major breakdown's are basically replacing all the parts. The Pontiac vibes are running better than GMC expected with the odometer freezing at 399,999. I brought a Pontiac vibe with 100,000 miles on it and with high mileage it work better than every American car that I have ever brought with high mileage. Honestly American cars are junk with they hit 100,000 miles. I will only buy Toyota or Honda and they are made in united States.

There is only one Japanese automaker that still makes cars the traditional Japanese way, Toyota. Nissan is run by a bunch of French executives who are more of “le cost killers” than even the GM executives were, loading up Nissan cars with cheap parts. Accordingly, Nissan has the worst quality and reliability among major Japanese brands, and also the worst relationship with suppliers due to Nissan’s constant demand of price cutting. Honda also fell in the trap of cost cutting and is introducing CVT transmission across its model line up, including Fit, Civic, Accord, and CR-V, fully knowing that CVT transmissions would fail at certain point.

That depends on what you’re looking for. If you want reliability, performance, and a dependable all-wheel drive system, you can’t go wrong with a Subaru. Maintenance is not only easy and affordable, but I’ve found (more so than with other manufacturers) that the employees of Subaru are consistently kind and helpful. They making buying and owning a car just a bit easier, which is one of the intangibles that makes Subaru’s cars better than the sums of their parts.

Subaru has one of the highest resale value on the market. My 2002 Subaru has a resale of 12,000 versus the blue book of 1000$. But is it a Japanese car? Not really. My car was assembled in Indiana. It had parts from all over the world, like most cars today.

response.answer_text: Here in Japan, the perception (particularly the one held by car dealers) is as Misako Fukuda says, Toyota first then Honda second, Nissan third.  That's why on a like-for-like comparison you'll pay a 5-10% premium for Toyota over a Honda and 5-10% on a Honda over a Nissan.

the Honda S500, S600, s800 literally took the American Marketplace by storm in totally changed our car culture forever. When those cars started showing up that was the beginning of the small car Revolution subsequently followed by higher energy prices and eventually the energy crisis peaking in the late 70s. Every single little foreign car you see on the road today can trace his lineage to those Honda cars that first came across the ocean and invaded America in the early 70s.

From my personal experience, Honda and Toyota are the most reliable Japanese cars, especially if you want to buy a used car. Actually, I consider there is no sense to buy a new car, a used car is cheaper and you can always check car history online. For example, I always check vin before buying here https://www.quickrevs.com.au/ppsr-check

You’ll consistently find many Japanese cars at the top of reliability lists. Check the results at TrueDelta -- Real Car Owners Driving Real Car Information for more specifics. You’ll find Hondas, Toyotas and Mazdas at the top of most categories.

The boy racers would say the Nissan Skyline. The rally drivers the Datsun 1600. The 4wd enthusiasts, the Toyota Landcruiser. The tradesmen, the Toyota Hilux. The classic car enthusiasts, the Prince Skyline.

According to almost all reports, Toyota, followed closely by Honda. It has been this way for MANY years, It surprises me that the USA manufacturers haven’t realized that they need to adapt the Japanese style of manufacturing and Quality,

Japanese cars are famous all over the world for their durability and reliability. But there are certain Japanese automakers that are more reliable than the others. Toyota and Honda said to be the most reliable car brands. If you are looking for reliable Japanese car you can go for Toyota corolla.
Best meaning: design and built, reliable and safety, serviceable and easy to drive. Toyota and Lexus vehicles surpasses these criteria.
Probably the toyota hilux. It’s been in production for over 50 years now and has been made in enormous numbers. IT’s also proven to be very durable, just search for hilux and top gear on youtube.
